artefact.overview: When to tell DVLA about a medical condition or disability - what will happen to your licence, getting a free tax disc, Motability scheme

parts.title: Telling DVLA about a medical condition or disability
parts.body:
If you have a driving licence you must tell DVLA if:

  • you have a ‘notifiable’ medical condition or disability
  • your medical condition or disability has got worse since you first got your licence
  • you develop a new medical condition or disability

Notifiable medical conditions

‘Notifiable’ medical conditions and disabilities include epilepsy, strokes and other neurological conditions, mental health problems, physical disabilities and visual impairments.

Check the health conditions that could affect your driving and how to tell DVLA.

parts.title: What happens after you tell DVLA
parts.body:
Surrendering your licence

If your doctor tells you to stop driving because of your medical condition you must surrender your licence to DVLA.

Car and motorcycle licence

Download and fill in the ‘Declaration of voluntary surrender’ form, and send it with your driving licence to DVLA. (The address is on the form.)

Download ‘Declaration of voluntary surrender’ (PDF, 35KB)

Bus, coach and lorry licence

Download and fill in VOC99/CERT form and send it with your driving licence to DVLA. (The address is on the form.)

Download ‘VOC99/CERT’ (PDF, 145KB)

After you’ve told DVLA about your condition

DVLA aim to make a decision within 3 weeks, however, if they need more information about your medical condition it could take up to 90 working days.

parts.title: What the DVLA will decide
parts.body:
Once DVLA has assessed your medical condition or disability you may:

  • get to keep your old licence or get a new one
  • be issued with a shorter period licence - for 1, 2 or 3 years, after which time your condition will need to be reviewed
  • you may need to adapt your car by fitting special controls
  • you may be told to stop driving and your licence taken away

Adapting your vehicle

If you have been told that you must adapt your car, you get an independent assessment of your adaptation needs through the Forum of Mobility Centres.

Find out more about adapting your vehicle and where to get special controls fitted through the Ricability charity.

If your licence is taken away

You’ll be given a medical reason why, and be told when you can re-apply for your licence. You’ll also be sent a notice that explains your right to appeal against the decision.

parts.title: Renewing or re-applying for your licence
parts.body:
If you’ve been issued with a short period driving licence, DVLA will send you renewal application documents 90 days before your licence is due to expire.

If your licence was taken away, you need to check with your doctor that you meet the medical standards of fitness to drive before you re-apply.

Find out how to re-apply for your licence if it was taken away following a medical condition.

parts.title: Driving with disabilities
parts.body:
Blue Badge scheme

The Blue Badge scheme helps disabled drivers park closer to their destinations.

Find out more information about the Blue Badge scheme from your local council.

Apply for a Blue Badge.

Tax disc exemptions

You may be entitled to a free tax disc if you’re disabled.

Getting your first free tax disc

If you have a new vehicle take your exemption certificate and valid insurance certificate to the dealership where you bought the vehicle.

With a used vehicle you can change to a free tax disc at a Post Office branch.

Download the leaflet for information on how to apply for your free tax disc for the first time

Find your nearest Post Office that issues tax discs - choose ‘driving licences’ from the drop down menu. Or you can telephone 0845 722 3344 giving your postcode.

Renewing your free tax disc

Renewing your free tax disc can be done online or by phone.

Renew your tax disc online or by phone.

Refunds on your current tax disc

Once you’ve got your disabled tax disc, you can apply for a refund if you’ve got any complete months remaining on your old tax disc.

Motability scheme

The Motability scheme is run by the independent charity Motability. It gives disabled people the chance to lease a car at an affordable price.

To find out more about the scheme contact Motability directly.

Motability
Telephone: 0845 456 4566
Textphone: 0845 675 0009
www.motability.co.uk

Apply for a dropped kerb

A ‘dropped kerb’ may make it easier to get from your car to your house. It involves lowering the kerbstones and making a small ramp from the road to your driveway.

You can apply for a dropped kerb outside your home if you live in England.
